author: ncsyannex
content: Hi, are stakers also rewarded a fixed 2eth fee for validating a block or is the reward system different?

author: ncsyannex
content: also are ethereum proof of stake and proof of work running in parallel

author: pietjepuk
content: To answer both your questions: They are indeed running in parallel. There already is a reward system for stakers (generating ETH), and that won't change (and it's not 2 ETH a block).

author: pietjepuk
content: Yearly inflation (pre EIP-1559 anyway) was about ~4% due to the 2 ETH a block for miners, and 0.5% due to rewards to stakers

author: duncancmt4886
content: Do non-EIP155 transactions still work? I know they can't be submitted over RPC, but can they still be included and mined under the right conditions? Follow-up: are there plans to completely remove EVM support for non-EIP155 transactions?

author: a7med_khalid
content: How can i start in contributing to etherum

author: sky.cactus
content: Yes, they still work.  No current plans to remove cross-chain transactions, but I don't recommend building something under the assumption that will be true forever.

author: duncancmt4886
content: Hmm... Is there another good way to trustlessly deploy the same contract to the same address on every EVM-based chain? My solution right now involves deploying a foothold contract using a single-use address in a non-EIP155 transaction and then using CREATE2 from that foothold contract to deploy the rest of the protocol. It's not a perfect solution (I can think of misleading ways to get different bytecode on different chains), but it prevents shenanigans with the foothold contract

author: treyzania
content: does the value added by having the same addresses on every chain outweigh the added complexity?

author: treyzania
content: that seems excessive
